content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. My mind just keeps racing with all these thoughts about work and how everything feels so unstable. I'm worried about getting fired, and it’s been stressing me out so much that I just can’t seem to shut my brain off at night. It’s like I’m constantly stuck in my own head, and nothing I try seems to help.

That sounds really overwhelming—having your mind race with worries about work and stability can take such a toll, especially when it's affecting your sleep. You're juggling a lot right now. What’s been most challenging for you in trying to manage these thoughts?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I can’t control them. I try to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but it just ends up adding more to think about. I know it’s not helping, but I don’t know what else to do when I can’t sleep. It’s exhausting.

It sounds like you're really trying to find ways to manage those racing thoughts, even though distractions like scrolling aren’t giving you the relief you’re looking for. It’s really tough when you feel stuck in that cycle and don’t know what else to do. What would it mean for you if you could find something that helped calm your mind and let you rest more easily?

I guess it would mean a lot—it would feel like I can finally have some peace and maybe even focus better during the day. It’s just hard to imagine what that “something” could even be when I’m so stuck in this loop.

Wanting peace and better focus during the day shows how much this matters to you, even in the midst of feeling stuck. You’ve already taken steps to try to manage it, which shows strength. If you could imagine just one small step forward—one thing that might help break the loop—what do you think that could look like for you?

I don’t know, honestly. Maybe putting my phone away at night could help, but I don’t know how to actually stick to that—it feels like my safety net when I can’t sleep. And even if I did, I don’t think it’ll stop the thoughts from spinning in my head. It’s all just much easier said than done.

Letting go of something that feels like a safety net can feel really uncertain, and it's understandable you'd worry about what happens next. It shows a lot of awareness that you're even considering that option. It seems like you're open to exploring ways to quiet your thoughts but unsure where to start. What matters most to you when you think about making a change like this—whether it’s about sleep, managing stress, or calming your mind?

What matters most is trying to feel like myself again and not waking up every day feeling drained. I want to be able to show up for my family—not just as someone who provides financially, but as someone who’s present for them emotionally too. I’m scared that nothing will work, though, and that I’ll just keep letting them down.

It’s clear how deeply you care about being there for your family, both emotionally and financially. It sounds like feeling drained is making it hard for you to be fully present in the way you want, and that's weighing heavily on your mind. Even though you're carrying so much right now, you're still thinking about how to make positive changes for yourself and your family—that’s a meaningful step. What would living more fully in the way you hope to look and feel like, even in small ways?

I think living like that would mean having the energy to really engage with my family and not feel so trapped in my own head all the time. Being able to sleep better would probably make a huge difference, so I’m not always so irritable or exhausted. I just want to feel like I’m doing right by them—and by myself.

It’s inspiring to hear how much you value showing up for your family and yourself. Connecting with them in meaningful ways and finding relief from feeling trapped in your thoughts sounds very important to you. You’re already reflecting on the impact sleep has on your energy and mood, and how it could help you move closer to the life you want. Is there anything else you feel is standing in your way of getting there, or something you’d like to explore more deeply?

I think it’s mainly the fear that even if I try to make changes, I’ll fail or that it won’t be enough to actually improve anything. It’s hard to feel motivated when I’m already running on empty. I guess I’m scared to hope too much, in case it just makes the disappointment worse.

Facing that fear of trying and not seeing change can make it feel even harder to begin, especially when you’re already dealing with exhaustion. It’s understandable to want to protect yourself from feeling disappointed, especially if it feels like there’s so much at stake. Starting small can sometimes feel more manageable. Is there any small step, no matter how tiny, that feels less daunting to you—or something you'd be curious about exploring to move toward what you hope for?

I think just starting with something simple like leaving my phone in another room at night could be a small step, but even that feels hard. It’s scary to imagine sitting alone with my thoughts, even for a little while. Maybe I could try it for a few minutes first and see how it goes, but I’m not sure if that’ll really help or just make things worse.

Starting with a small, manageable step like leaving your phone in another room, even for just a few minutes, is a brave idea. Feeling uncertain or scared about it is understandable—those thoughts can feel overwhelming when they’re unfiltered. Trying it gradually, like you mentioned, could be a gentle way to experiment without putting too much pressure on yourself. What would help you feel supported or grounded in taking that first step?

I think having something else to focus on, like maybe writing down some of my thoughts or even just practicing deep breathing, might help. That way, it’s not just me alone with my racing mind. It still feels hard, but maybe if I had some kind of routine to fall back on, it would be easier to keep trying.

Having a routine with something grounding, like writing your thoughts or practicing deep breathing, sounds like a thoughtful way to manage those moments and give your mind a focal point. You’re already exploring ways to ease into this change, and that sense of care for yourself really stands out. Would it feel helpful to think more about how to create this routine—or is there anything else that’s important for you to talk about right now?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
